occurrences.line_text: Didst thou behight me borne of English blood,
Vnto the iourney which he had behight:
My Lord (quoth he) me sent, and streight behight
At last him turning to his charge behight,
The Ferriman, as Alma had behight,
So taking courteous conge he behight,
That Geauntesse Argante is behight,
A Knight much better then thy selfe behight,
And lowly to her lowting thus behight;
Him dead behight, as he to all appeard,
The second was to Triamond behight,
Till Britomart him fairely thus behight;
And for his paines a whistle him behight
Whom soone as he beheld, he knew, and thus behight.
So fild with heauenly fury, thus he her behight.
Both it and all the wealth therein behight
Yet for the time this answere he to him behight.
So with her marched forth, as she did him behight.
Behind her farre away a Dwarfe did lag,
His seuenfold teme behind the stedfast starre,
The faire Duess' had forst him leaue behind;
The gentle virgin left behind alone
His wearie limbes vpon: and eke behind,
His speare of heben wood behind him bare,
But leauing all behind her, fled away:
But at her rompe she growing had behind
As if his feare still followed him behind;
Not purg'd nor heald, behind remained still,
It sweepeth all the land behind him farre,
Behind his backe vnweeting, where he stood,
Before, behind, and round about him layes:
Or fly away, or bide alone behind:
And him behind, a wicked Hag did stalke,
But all behind was bald, and worne away,
And both his hands fast bound behind his backe,
Behind his backe he bore a brasen shield,
His sandy lockes, long hanging downe behind,
Hauing his warlike weapons cast behind,
Soone she that Island farre behind her left,
Guyon was loath to leaue his guide behind,
Leauing behind them griefe and heauinesse.
Did shut, and from behind it forth there lept
The which with monstrous stalke behind him stept,
That dreadfull feend, which did behind him wayt,
Loe where the dreadfull Death behind thy backe doth stond.
But casting wrongs and all reuenge behind,
The traine whereof loose far behind her strayd,
Ne ought I weene are ye therein behind,
And therefore was remoued farre behind,
And fast the land behind them fled away.
Least that his Lord they should behind inuade;
That halfe the steele behind his back did rest;
Whiles the dred daunger does behind remaine.
But th'other by his boate behind did stay.
Nigh a speares length behind his crouper fell,
And her faire yellow locks behind her flew,
Ne reckt of Ladies Loue, did stay behind,
Ne bubbling roundell they behind them sent;
The want of his good Squire late left behind,
Soone as she Venus saw behind her backe,
Were hard behind, her readie to arrest:
Which Florimell had left behind her late,
And tyde behind his charet, to aggrate
Ne long shall Satyrane behind you stay,
So forth they far'd, but he behind them stayd,
And loth to leaue his liefest pelfe behind,
And in his eare him rounded close behind:
Here for to stay in safetie behind;
And neuer looked, who behind him was,
Did all the way him follow hard behind,
Whom when as Britomart beheld behind
And seeing him behind a straunger knight,
Reproch the first, Shame next, Repent behind:
Sir knight why ride ye dumpish thus behind,
And left the head behind: with which despight
The other halfe behind yet sticking fast,
And left behind her in her secret bowre,
That in her wheeling round, behind her crest
That quite it chynd his backe behind the sell,
To Scudamour, who she had left behind:
When suddenly behind her backe she heard
Loe hard behind his backe his foe was prest,
And both behind vpheld her spredding traine;
Such as behind their backs (so backward bred)
That they haue him enclosed so behind,
The other stayd behind to gard the pray.
Who all this while behind him did remaine,
They left behind them, glad to be so quit:
Vppon that gibbet, which is there behind,
Yet still the Prince pursew'd him close behind,
Bit him behind, that long the marke was to be read.
He rather should haue taken vp behind.
Vnto the place, where me he left behind:
Had left behind, he gan eftsoones prepare,
Ne durst abide behind, for dread of worse effort.
Behind the bushes, where she her did hyde,
And low behinde her backe were scattered:
Ne was Sir Satyrane her far behinde,
Behinde him was Reproch, Repentance, Shame;
And each not farre behinde him had his make,
Behinde the gate, that none her might espy;
Ne was Sir Artegall behinde: so both
With both his hands behinde him pinnoed hard,
Behinde, beside, before, as he it list apply.
To hide the horrour, which did lurke behinde,
To take him vp behinde vpon his steed:
If I would beare behinde a burden of such scorne.
Behinde his Ladies backe, who to him cryde,
And creeping still behinde, doth him incomber,
Creeping behinde him still to haue destroyde:
Feeling some curre behinde his heeles to bite,
And in this bag which I behinde me don,
And is behinde me trodden downe of Scorne,
Did neuer mortall eye behold such heauenly grace.
Her from her Palfrey pluckt, her visage to behold.
Ah heauens, that do this hideous act behold,
Her to behold do thither runne apace,
In secret shadow, all this to behold,
Ne durst behold: his stature did exceed
That doe this deadly spectacle behold,
Whose fall did neuer foe before behold;
Behold what ye this day haue done for mee,
But very vncouth sight was to behold,
That greatest Princes presence might behold.
Such as she was, their eyes might her behold,
The author of this fact, we here behold,
Is not he iust, that all this doth behold
That horrour made to all, that did behold;
When him his dearest Vna did behold,
Playing their sports, that ioyd her to behold,
As Eagles eye, that can behold the Sunne:
High heauen behold the tedious toyle, ye for me take.
From whence she might behold that battailles proof
Behold I see the hauen nigh at hand,
Then when his daughter deare he does behold,
And euer, when his eye did her behold,
In this faire mirrhour maist behold thy face,
That feeble eyes your glory may behold,
Whom when the good Sir Guyon did behold,
Vouchsafed to behold vs from aboue,
Behold the image of mortalitie,
Or to behold the water worke, and play
Behold, Ã´ man, that toilesome paines doest take
And hid in darkenesse, that none could behold
Behold, thou Faeries sonne, with mortall eye,
That goodly was their glory to behold,
Which to behold, he clomb vp to the banke,
In which the damned soules he did behold,
Behold this heauie sight, thou reuerend Sire,
Behold, who list, both one and other in this place.
That sonnes of men amazd their sternnesse to behold.
Behold the boyling Bathes at Cairbadon,
Thus said; Behold th'ensamples in our sights,
Which seem'd to fly for feare, them to behold:
Thus being entred, they behold around
Them to behold, and in his sparkling face
Need but behold the pourtraict of her hart,
And scarse them leasure gaue, her passing to behold.
By strange occasion she did him behold,
Behold the man, and tell me Britomart,
A fairer wight did neuer Sunne behold,
Behold, Sir, how your pitifull complaint
The same behold, therewith their keene desires were whet.
(Ah man beware, how thou those darts behold)
And as she lookt about, she did behold,
Of chearefull looke and louely to behold;
Faire Dame he might behold in perfect kind;
They which from shore behold the dreadfull sight
Of people, thronging thicke her to behold,
And that both shield and she whom I behold,
An hideous Giant, dreadfull to behold,
But soone as they his countenance did behold,
Vnwilling to behold that louely band.
Whilest thus I spake, behold with happy eye
Chopt off, and nayld on high, that all might the[m] behold.
All that behold so strange prodigious sight,
And dare euen deathes most dreadfull face behold?
At such a chaunge, and ioyed to behold
And Ventailes reare, each other to behold.
Where they a stately pallace did behold,
Most richly made, but there no Monster did behold.
Whom when they thus distressed did behold,
At last some fisher barke doth neare behold,
Whom when as he thus combred did behold,
That euen I which daily doe behold
Whom whylest she did with watrie eyne behold,
The fairest peece, that eye beholden can:
That could haue dazd the rash beholders sight,
That quite bereau'd the rash beholders sight:
And with their brightnesse daz'd the straunge beholders eye.
They all beholding worldly wights in place,
That men beholding so great excellence,
Beholding it from far, do thinke it threates the skye.
The warlike Mayde beholding earnestly
Beholding how the thrids of life they span:
But Artegall beholding his mischaunce,
She her beholding with attentiue eye,
He her beholding, at her feet downe fell,
That faire Poeana them beholding both,
Past forth on foote, beholding all the way
Beholding all that womanish weake fight;
And when he long had him beholding stood,
Stood on the further bancke beholding him,
The fearefull swayne beholding death so nie,
Dayly beholding the faire Pastorell,
Beholding all, yet of them vnespyde.
Whom she beholding, now all desolate
Beholds her Nymphes, enraung'd in shadie wood,
High heauen beholds sad louers nightly theeueryes.
And framed speaches fit for his behoofe,
But Cordeill said she lou'd him, as behoou'd:
Ne liuing wight would haue him life behot:
Sir Brianor, so sore, that none him life behote.
Of falshood or of slouth, when most it may behoue.
Whom hauing wedded as did him behoue,
That where ye left, I may her seeke, as doth behoue.
Did well accept, as well it did behoue,
Ne lend an eare to ought, that might behoue,
To all of each degree, as doth behoue?
And as it mote a faithfull friend behoue,
Saying and doing all that mote behoue;
And honourd him, with all that her behoued.
Him well behoued so; for his three foes
And fained cheare, as for the time behoues,
But me behoueth rather to vpbrayd,
Here now behoueth vs well to auyse,
It was a goodly heape for to behould,
Wondrous delight it was, there to behould,
Whose goodly building when she did behould,
Full fast she fled, ne euer lookt behynd,
More for the loue which he had left behynd,
with th'Hermit leaues behynd.
Was forced there to leaue them both behynd,
He had behynd him left that saluage wight,
But with his whip him following behynd,
And yet his feare did follow him behynd:
That lasie seemd in being euer last,
At her wide mouth: but being there withstood
Which being taught, he forward gan aduaunce
Being in deed old Archimage, did stay
The sixt had charge of them now being dead,
Being arriued, where that champion stout
Did paint his chearefull cheekes, yet being ded,
Being diffused through the senselesse truncke,
As when a Beare and Tygre being met
Now little gan to swell, and being tide,
And being downe the villein sore did beat,
Being at last recured, he gan inquire,
Yet being entred, might not backe retyre;
And being on his way, approched neare,
His wanton sports, being returned late
Coulin to make, being eight lugs of grownd;
In which being consorted with Manild,
But being all defeated, saue a few,
Her to rebuke, for being loose and light:
Thus being entred, they behold around
No gate, but like one, being goodly dight
Yet being men they did vnmanly looke,
Being his onely daughter and his hayre;
And fetch their being from the sacred mould
Yet former feare of being fowly shent,
And light doe shonne, for feare of being shent:
She made those Damzels search, which being stayd,
And all the Graces rockt her cradle being borne.
Being through former bathing mollifide,
All things from thence doe their first being fetch,
Whilome begot, being but halfe twin of that berth.
Being possessed of that spoyle, which seemed
For being fled into the fishers bote,
Like as Minerua, being late returnd
Abounded, being glad of so fit tyde
Sith all thy worthy prayses being blent,
And gaue him being, commune to them twaine:
Yet inly being more, then seeming sad:
Being thereof beguyld was fild with new affright.
Who being asked for his loue, auow'd
That being forst his saddle soone to leaue,
But being past, he thus began amaine;
And being dead in vaine yet many striue:
Some fearing shriekt, some being harmed hould,
Who being freed, from one a weapon fiercely takes.
And now by this their feast all being ended,
This being ended thus, and all agreed,
Which being once withdrawne, most perfect hew
Which being brought, about her middle small
Who being askt, accordingly confessed all.
Which being yeelded, he his threatfull speare
Which being knit with vertue, neuer will remoue.
So peace being confirm'd amongst them all,
All being guided by Sir Artegall.
Which being whylome launcht with louely dart,
The Squire her loues, and being blam'd
That being mou'd with ruth she thus bespake.
Being likewise beguiled in her thought,
Gan blame me much for being so vntrew,
Whence being forth produc'd, when she perceiued
But being doubly smitten likewise doubly smit.
The Prince yet being fresh vntoucht afore;
And being brought in daunger, to relent too late.
But now his courage being throughly fired,
But being in, Delay in close awaite
That being free from feare and gealosye,
But being faire and brickle, likest glasse did seeme.
And sharpe rebuke, for being ouer bold;
These three faire sons, which being the[n]ce forth powrd
But for he was halfe mortall, being bred
Yet hoping griefe may lessen being told,
Being returned to his mothers bowre,
Which being ment of mortall creatures sead,
And shewed her to him, then being sore bestad.
And being once amisse growes daily wourse and wourse.
And fain'd to fly for feare of being thrall;
There being both together in the floud,
His horses backe, for dread of being drownd,
Who being entred, nought did then auaile
Who being freed from Proteus cruell band
Either by being wreckt vppon the sands,
Or being carried farre from forraine lands.
Being the dowry of his wife well knowne,
Being desirous (as all Knights are woont)
For being ouercome by her in fight,
And now the Knights being arriued neare,
So being clad, she brought him from the field,
Being fast fixed in her wounded spright,
Ne to himselfe, for doubt of being sdayned,
Against her Knight, for being so vntrew;
Yet being forst to abide the daies returning,
As being troubled with that stormy stowre;
To hide thy state from being vnderstood?
Where being layd, the wrothfull Britonesse
They being chased, that did others chase.
Being impatient of impediment,
Which being wounded of the huntsmans hand
But Artegall being thereof aware,
Being returned to his former hew:
Being then new made widow (as befell)
Which being shew'd, he gan him selfe streight way
To issue forth; the which once being brust,
That bloudie scutchin being battered sore,
Taken in hand th'exploit, being theretoo
Did forth descend, there being none them neare,
By the way side being together set,
Being all rag'd and tatter'd, their disgraces
Planted in earth, being deriu'd at furst
Yet being matcht with plaine Antiquitie,
And being moou'd with pittie of my plight,
And being now high time these strong ioynts to imploy.
Being vnarm'd, and set in secret shade.
Being vnhable else alone to ride;
Being oppressed by that faytour bold,
Vpon him ran; who being well prepard,
To send her succour, being of all hope forlore.
And sau'd from being to that caitiue thrall.
Being vnable to digest that bone;
Being now soft and fit them to embrace;
Being with fame through many Nations blowen,
But Calepine, now being left alone
Like this wyld man, being vndisciplynd,
And being thereon mounted, forth did pace,
Like a wylde Bull, that being at a bay,
Which being all with Yuy ouerspred,
But being aged now and weary to
But being well suffiz'd, them rested faine.
And being such, were now much more increast,
But being now attacht with timely age,
But being growen strong, it forth doth bring
Yet for no bidding, nor for being shent,
Like a fierce Bull, that being busie bent
And being fresh and full of youthly spright,
And being carried with his force forthright,
Till the sharpe passion being ouerpast,
But being vp, he lookt againe aloft,
Who was so far from being ought amazed,
But being checkt, he did abstaine streight way,
For being of his loue to her so light,
Where being tyrde with trauell, and opprest
Now being naked, to their sordid eyes
So being stayd, they her from thence directed
Being alreadie dead with fearefull fright.
Till being waked with these loud alarmes,
Their tender flocks, now being fully fed,
Being his harts owne wish, and home with him did go.
But being bred vnder base shepheards wings,
So being clad, vnto the fields he went
Being now placed in the firmament,
For being gone, none can them bring in place,
He ran at him enrag[e]d in stead of being frayde.
Who being now in dreadfull darknesse layd,
T'inquire for slaues; where being readie met
Whose whelpes are stolne away, she being otherwhere.
Like him that being long in tempest tost,
To leaue his Loue, now perill being past,
Vnto her mistresse, being halfe dismayd,
And being downe, ere he new helpe could call,
And her salewd with seemely belaccoyle,
Ne yet her Belamour, the partner of his sheet.
Therein to shrowd her sumptuous Belamoure,
To the faire Critias his dearest Belamy.
Of Lincolne greene, belayd with siluer lace;
Doth belch out flames, and rockes in peeces broke,
And belcheth forth his superfluity,
Beldame, your words doe worke me litle ease;
And to her said, Beldame, by that ye tell,
Her mildly answer'd; Beldame be not wroth
And of his aged Beldame homely well;
And then too well beleeu'd, that which tofore
The knights beleeu'd, that all he sayd, was trew,
Then womans shape man would beleeue to bee.
Least thou of her beleeue too lightly blame,
Soone shalt thou see, and then beleeue for troth,
Did easily beleeue her strong extremitie.
Though nought beleu'd, & entrau[n]ce late did not refuse.
Vnto the Castle of Belgard her brought,
In speaking, many false belgardes at her let fly.
Working belgards, and amorous retrate,
And came to this, where Belge then did dwell,
Belge vnto her right.
As by sad Belge seemes, whose wrongs though long
How that the Lady Belge now had found
But Belge with her sonnes prostrated low
And Belge selfe was therewith stonied sore,
With Belge, who watcht all this while full sad,
There he with Belge did a while remaine,
Full loath to Belge, and to all the rest:
Who for like cause faire Belge did oppresse,
for Belgee for to fight:
he slayes in Belges right.
Stretch her white rod ouer the Belgicke shore,
Her name was Belgï¿½, who in former age
Full easie was for her to haue beliefe,
And made her famous, more then is belieued;
When one so oft a night did ring his matins bell.
So Satyrane that day was iudg'd to beare the bell.
That she should surely beare the bell away,
First rings his siluer Bell t'each sleepy wight,
Aboue all other lasses beare the bell,
And Bellamour againe so well her pleased,
Nathlesse Sir Bellamour, whether through grace
And Bellamour in bands, till that her syre
For Bellamour knew Calidore right well,
With thanks to Bellamour and Claribell,
Whereof was Lord the good Sir Bellamoure;
Of loue to Bellamoure empierced were,
Like belles in greatnesse orderly succeed,
Her tender sides, her bellie white and clere,
Their bellies swolne he saw with fulnesse burst,
Of Brennus and Bellinus, kings of Britany.
Next them did Gurgunt, great Bellinus sonne
The second had to name Sir Bellisont,
Is for the sake of Bellodant the bold,
Some, that Bellona in that warlike wise
And blow the bellowes to his swelling vanity.
One with great bellowes gathered filling aire,
An huge great paire of bellowes, which did styre
And eke the breathfull bellowes blew amaine,
The bellowes noyse disturb'd his quiet rest,
And threats his horns, and bellowes like the thonder,
Which through the wood loud bellowing, did rebownd,
And fill the fields with troublous bellowing,
Breathing out wrath, and bellowing disdaine,
Ere long they heard an hideous bellowing
Those Pensifenesse did moue; and Sighes the bellows weare.
His belly was vp-blowne with luxury,
But both from backe and belly still did spare,
Till that with timely fruit her belly sweld,
Wondred to see her belly so vpblone,
What time the natiue Belman of the night,
And vppon all those Knights, that did to her belong.
That vnto him the horse belong'd, and sayd;
To you th'inheritance belongs by right
Faire Florimell belou'd of many a knight,
Vnworthy she to be belou'd so dere,
I was belou'd of many a gentle Knight,
To visite her beloued Paramoure,
And stolne away from her beloued mate,
And of my lifes deare loue beloued be:
With th'Elfin Knight, her Ladies best beloued;
Of both beloued well, but litle frended;
With her two sonnes, right deare of her beloued,
Then Calidore, beloued ouer all,
With a faire Damzell, my beloued deare,
To draw him from his deare beloued dame,
Below her ham her weed were somewhat traine,
Great Mammon, greatest god below the skye,
Below the earth, might suffred be to stay:
All the huge threasure, which the sea below
And brutish shape thrust downe to hell below,
Till that young Squire him reared from below;
Which hunt for honor, raised from below,
To enter in, or issue forth below:
And gan entreat that iron man below,
She heard a wondrous noise below the hall.
An hideous tempest seemed from below,
Belphebe finds him almost dead,
Belphebe saues from dread:
It fortuned Belphebe with her peares
Belphebe raunging in that forrest wide,
That mou'd Belphebe her no lesse to hate,
Which was by him BELPHEBE rightly rad.
Yet who was that Belphebe, he ne wist;
